articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description:
When viewing the uncanny scenes of Munich-based artist Quint Buchholz, itâ€™s evident that play, experimentation, and exploring the uncharted are central tenets of his practice: a string quintet precariously balances above the sea, sightseers take advantage of the view atop a giant man, and a pigeon doubles as an apartment complex.
Each piece toys with scale and sensibility, and Buchholz enlarges some characters to preposterous sizes while positioning others in strange, seemingly impossible situations. More
articles.title: Playfully Surreal Scenarios Emerge from Innumerable Acrylic Dots in Quint Buchholzâ€™s Paintings

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: In June of 2020, Polly Irungu launched Black Women Photographers with about 100 members and the hope that more Black women would receive commissions and greater recognition for their work. â€œI didnâ€™t really know that photography was a space for me to be in, as I didnâ€™t see myself in the world of photography or really any art spaces for that reason,â€ Irungu said about the impetus for the organization in a recent interview. More
articles.title: Black Women Photographers Is a Global Community at the Forefront of a Changing Industry

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: Fusing history with the political and social contexts of today, Ocom Adoniasâ€™s work interprets the experience of moving through the world in a Black body. His vibrant, realistic paintings portray people in ordinary moments of ritual, solitude, and bonding, honing in on individual narratives to convey a broader message. â€œIâ€™m particularly interested in the global conversation of what being an African and what being Black means, history, and the representation of the Black figure in the contemporary sense,â€ he shares. More
articles.title: In Introspective Paintings, Artist Ocom Adonias Explores Narratives of Blackness

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: The late artist and author Maurice Sendak is responsible for bringing us some of the most beloved, iconic childhood stories, and his distinctive style and fantastical beasts defined classics like In the Night Kitchen, Outside Over There, and of course, the ever-popular Where the Wild Things Are. Opening this fall at the Columbus Museum of Art, an expansive retrospective surveys Sendakâ€™s unparalleled contributions to both childrenâ€™s literature and the discipline, more broadly. More
articles.title: Let the Wild Rumpus Start! A Retrospective Celebrates the Illustrated Classics of the Late Maurice Sendak

articles.author: Kate Mothes
articles.description: Embodying the bleary-eyed feeling of an early morning, insomnia, or a long, lazy day at home, artist Ikuo Inadaâ€™s meditative sculptures personify sleepiness. The Japanese artistâ€™s meticulously carved, realistic figures clutch feather pillows, envelop themselves in comforters, or stand drowsily in soft hoodies. His ambiguous subjects, often half-hidden in a sweatshirt or a blanket, are usually between one and three feet tall and carved from a single block of wood, allowing the natural grain to complement the delicately chiseled hem of a shirt, a drawstring, and slender fingers and toes. More
articles.title: Lethargic Sleepyheads Loaf in Pajamas in Ikuo Inadaâ€™s Meticulous and Contemplative Sculptures

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: From her studio in Canberra, Australian artist Sally Blake (previously) twists and plaits copper wire into baskets and sculptures evocative of the organic matter ubiquitous around the planet. Seed pods, sprawling networks of bulbous pockets and thin, sinuous veins, and mammalian bronchial systems emerge from the malleable material, and through intricately woven motifs, Blake accentuates the tension between delicacy and resilience inherent to natural life. â€œVisualisation of the natural laws and patterning that hold people in relationship with Earth, as well as the consequences of these unravelling, is my focus,â€ she tells Colossal. More
articles.title: Vessels of Woven Copper Wire by Sally Blake Mimic the Patterns of Natural Lifeforms

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: Berlin-based artist Uli KnoÌˆrzer (previously) highlights the signature grainy texture of colored pencils in his faithful portraiture. Whether for personal projects or commissions from fashion labels and publicationsâ€”many of the pieces shown here are part of a recent project for Tommy Hilfigerâ€”the richly illustrated works hone in on the emotions of the subject. By positioning the figures against monochromatic backdrops devoid of setting, he accentuates the minute details of their facial expressions and body language. More
articles.title: Grainy Colored Pencil Portraits by Uli KnoÌˆrzer Emphasize a Subjectâ€™s Distinct Demeanor

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description: Playfully curious, a troupe of hybrid characters dreamed up by the Brazil-based Toco-Oco (previously) has an inclination for the mythical. Figures sporting feathered suits and wolves cradling human heads are imbued with mystery, and together, the otherworldly cast becomes a metaphor for the varied, emotional, and sometimes bewildering nature of human existence. Toco-Oco, which is helmed by Lara AlcÃ¢ntara and Guilherme Neumann, sells prints and the small sculptures, which are made of wax, wood, and clay, in its shop, although the works sell out incredibly quickly, so be sure to keep an eye on Instagram for information about new releases. More
articles.title: Fantastical Hybrid Characters by Toco-Oco Imagine the Mysteries of Human Nature

articles.author: Kate Mothes
articles.description: Glasgow-based artist Lola Dupreâ€™s evocative and often humorous photographic collages of animals, historic images, and portraits tap into the unique personalities and emotions of her subjects. A cross-eyed cat has its vision multiplied, and a Shiba Inuâ€™s joyful face pokes out of an enormous body in a play on repetition and perception. Dupre captures a range of expressions in both human and animal form (previously), exaggerating a raised eyebrow or fuzzy paw by layering numerous pieces of paper to extend legs, arm, eyes, and other features. More
articles.title: Humor Infuses Exaggerated Features in Lola Dupreâ€™s Meticulously Distorted Collages

articles.author: Grace Ebert
articles.description:
From his studio in northern California, artist Jon Carling summons the metaphysical by scrawling scenes tinged with magic and whimsy. He works in pen and pencil, layering lines and wispy markings into a wave of florals enveloping a levitating figure or a beam radiating from a womanâ€™s eyes. Many of the works feature an element of hidden sorcery, veiling the largely natural subject matter with mysteriously powerful energy.
Although devoid of color, Carlingâ€™s drawings capture the trippy, psychedelic imaginations associated with the rock music that dominated the Sixties and Seventies and provided the soundtrack for his childhood home. More
articles.title: Scratchy Pencil-and-Ink Drawings by Jon Carling Conjure Mythical Beings and Surreal Sorcery

articles.author: Sabina Graves
articles.description:
The trickle of trick-or-treat time goods has continued at popular retailers. Warner Bros. horror is making a big stamp at places like Hot Topic and Lowes. Spirit Halloween has debuted new exclusives as more of its locations open up. And kids are back in school, so those creepyÂ Target aisles should be upon us soon. 
Read more...
articles.title: Code Orange! More New Horror Movie and TV-Themed Halloween Fashion and Accessories

articles.author: Germain Lussier
articles.description:
Spider-Man: No Way Home is coming back to theaters next month, and if it makes another $100 million, it would be only the sixth movie in cinema history to cross $2 billion worldwide. What could possibly get people to come back and see the Marvel mega-hit? How about 11 minutes of new footage?
Read more...
articles.title: The Spider-Man: No Way Home Extended Edition Is 11 Minutes Longer

articles.author: Passant Rabie
articles.description:
Itâ€™s been 20 years since someone first held up their phone to a speaker playing a vaguely familiar tune and wondered, â€œwait, who sings this?â€ The music recognition app Shazam celebrated its 20th anniversary by releasing a playlist of the most searched songs over the past two decades.
Read more...
articles.title: The Music You Just Can't Recognize: Most 'Shazamed' Songs Across 7 Genres

articles.author: James Whitbrook
articles.description:
Thereâ€™s more Star Trek now than thereâ€™s ever been in the franchiseâ€™s history. Legendary shows, new hits, and more Trek appealing to more people than ever before. It can make jumping on board really hardâ€”but the beauty of Star Trek is that you can kind of start anywhere. Hereâ€™s the best places to warp into Star Trek,â€¦
Read more...
articles.title: Where to Start With Star Trek

articles.author: Dell Cameron
articles.description:
The House of Representatives approved changes to next yearâ€™s military budget requiring the Department of Defense to start disclosing any purchases of smartphone or web browsing data for which a warrant would ordinarily be required last month.

Read more...
articles.title: New Pentagon Budget Could Force the Military to Disclose When it Buys Americansâ€™ Location Data

articles.author: Passant Rabie
articles.description:
NASA is going back to the Moon, but first the space agency needs to decide where itâ€™s going to park. On Friday, it revealed 13 candidate landing regions near the Moonâ€™s south pole for the upcoming Artemis 3 mission, which aims to land a man and a woman on the lunar surface.
Read more...
articles.title: NASA Selects the Sites on the Moon Where Two Astronauts Could Land in 2026

articles.author: Sabina Graves and Artem Golub
articles.description: Read more...
articles.title: Spoilers of the Week: August 19th

articles.author: Florence Ion
articles.description:
Android 13 is here for Googleâ€™s Pixel devices, and if youâ€™re wielding a compatible model, you can grab the software now by requesting the over-the-air update in the settings panel. The software update is available for the Pixel 4 and up, including the latest Pixel 6a release. Note that this is a staggered rollout, soâ€¦
Read more...
articles.title: Android 13 Is a Subtle Improvement Over Android 12

articles.author: Molly Taft
articles.description:
When a huge plastic producer like Coca-Cola says itâ€™s working to solve the plastic crisis, what does that really look like? An investigation published Friday by Bloomberg documents how one initiative in Ghana was used by some of the worldâ€™s biggest plastic producers to battle against threats of plastic bans, whileâ€¦
Read more...
articles.title: How Coca-Cola, Unilever, and Others Delay Action on Plastic

articles.author: Lauren Leffer
articles.description:
Donald Trump-owned social media site, Truth Social, has seen a big influx of interest and new users following last weekâ€™s widely-publicized FBI raid on the former presidentâ€™s Florida home.

Read more...
articles.title: New Users Have Flocked to Trump's Truth Social in the Aftermath of FBI Raids

articles.author: Kevin Hurler
articles.description:
Richard Dabate, the husband of 2015 murder victim Connie Dabate, was sentenced to 65 years in prison on Thursday. Prosecutors say that Richard Dabateâ€™s police statements describing the murder did not match data present on Connieâ€™s wearable activity tracker, Fitbit.

Read more...
articles.title: Fitbit Murder: Husband of Slain Wife Sentenced to 65 Years

articles.author: Ed Cara
articles.description:
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is raising alarm over what it describes as a â€œfast-movingâ€ outbreak of Escherichia coli bacteria. At least 29 people in Michigan and Ohio have been sickened by the same strain, while nine have been hospitalized, but more cases may emerge. A clear cause for the foodborneâ€¦
Read more...
articles.title: A 'Fast-Moving' E. Coli Outbreak Is Hospitalizing People in the Midwest, CDC Warns
